head.title: The Rich, the Poor And the Microbe

hedline.hl1: The Rich, the Poor And the Microbe

abstract.p: Dr Nicholas S Hellman letter responds to June 18 editorial on rise of drug-resistant microbes; asserts trend should be of concern to wealthiest and poorest nations alike and requires cooperation of academic, government and commercial researchers

block.p: ''Losing Ground Against Microbes'' (editorial, June 18) rightly highlights the World Health Organization's concern about the illusion that merely having a drug is equivalent to curing a disease.

Part of the crisis is medicine's appalling lack of attention to the behavioral side of the health equation, the side that asks questions like: Who goes to the doctor; who prescribes which pills under what conditions and with what instructions; who is prescribed medicine and what the patients understand about its effects; why patients do or don't fill the prescription or, if they do, why they don't actually take the medicine.
''Losing Ground Against Microbes'' (editorial, June 18) rightly highlights the World Health Organization's concern about the illusion that merely having a drug is equivalent to curing a disease.

Part of the crisis is medicine's appalling lack of attention to the behavioral side of the health equation, the side that asks questions like: Who goes to the doctor; who prescribes which pills under what conditions and with what instructions; who is prescribed medicine and what the patients understand about its effects; why patients do or don't fill the prescription or, if they do, why they don't actually take the medicine.
These questions potentially affect more people than rogue microbes but receive negligible interest from scientists and even less research support.
The writer is executive director, Center for the Advancement of Health.
